qas.question: Which two countries sought to crush the nascent republic?
What had happened to most of the people who fled Sungau during the war when they were allowed to return home?

answers.text: lands and homes had been confiscated

qas.question: What was the name of the poem by Goethe?
Who was sympathetic to the Jacobins?
Where did the Austrian and Prussian armies make pilgrimages to?
When was the French Revolutionary Army victorious?
When was Hermann and Dorothea published?

context: At the same time, <b3_0>some Alsatians<b3_0/> were in opposition to the Jacobins and sympathetic to the invading forces of <a0_0>Austria and Prussia<a0_0/> who sought to crush the nascent revolutionary republic. Many of the residents of the Sundgau made "pilgrimages" to places like <b4_0>Mariastein Abbey,<b4_0/> near Basel, in Switzerland, for baptisms and weddings. When the French Revolutionary Army of the Rhine was victorious, <b7_0>tens of thousands<b7_0/> fled east before it. When they were later permitted to return (in some cases not until <b5_0>1799<b5_0/>), it was often to find that their <a1_0>lands and homes had been confiscated<a1_0/>. These conditions led to emigration by hundreds of families to newly vacant lands in the Russian Empire in 1803–4 and again in <b6_0>1808<b6_0/>. A poignant retelling of this event based on what Goethe had personally witnessed can be found in his long poem <a2_0>Hermann and Dorothea<a2_0/>.
